Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, \u00a.proposition: Plaintiff Jordan Lee (“Plaintiff”), residing at 345 Walnut Street, Roxbury, Massachusetts, brings this action against Defendant Martha Johnson (“Defendant”), Plaintiff’s landlord, for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, § 14.

c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, § 14 and c. 218, § 19, as this case involves a residential landlord-tenant dispute and the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limit of the Boston Municipal Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Roxbury Division of the Boston Municipal Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 2, as the property at issue is located in Roxbury, Massachusetts.

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that a landlord’s failure to address unsafe conditions or habitability issues constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The case explicitly rejects treating these unsafe, crime-ridden conditions as a breach of the warranty of habitability, but it does not frame them as habitability issues in connection with quiet enjoyment. Instead, it holds that a landlord’s failure to take reasonable measures to address third-party criminal activity that seriously interferes with tenants’ use of common areas may constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The opinion focuses on interference with use (quiet enjoyment), not on habitability doctrine, so it does not support the specific proposition that failure to address habitability issues constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that a landlord’s failure to address unsafe conditions or habitability issues constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely connects the landlord’s failure to maintain safe and sanitary conditions (repeated flooding with water and sewage, porous walls, violation of the State Sanitary Code) to liability for interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, which is an expanded statutory version of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court explains that “quiet enjoyment” covers serious interferences with the tenancy and expressly holds Gem liable under § 14 because it violated its duty to maintain sanitary conditions and allowed repeated flooding that interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment. That directly supports the proposition that failure to address unsafe or habitability conditions can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment in Massachusetts.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy… Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under G. L. c. 186, § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.proposition: Defendant’s failure to address the water intrusion problem, despite receiving notice from Plaintiff and the City of Boston, constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.support_reasoning: The case directly holds that a landlord’s negligent failure to repair known defects, after receiving notice, can constitute a breach of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The Court cites prior cases involving failure to repair water-related defects (e.g., leaky roof, flooding) as paradigmatic § 14 violations, and clarifies that when a landlord has notice of a problem and fails to take appropriate corrective measures, liability under the covenant may be imposed. Thus, a defendant’s failure to address water intrusion after notice fits squarely within the principle articulated in this opinion.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof)… Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord… it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of [the condition] and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.

*Dartmouth v. Posner*, 18 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Defendant’s failure to address the water intrusion problem, despite receiving notice from Plaintiff and the City of Boston, constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Dartmouth v. Posner*, 18 Mass. App. Ct..case_name: Bottom Line Associates, Inc. v. International Data Group, Inc.
*Dartmouth v. Posner*, 18 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a contract dispute over television advertising fees and does not involve landlord‑tenant law, covenants of quiet enjoyment, water intrusion, or any habitability/maintenance issues. Nothing in the case addresses whether a failure to remedy water intrusion after notice constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for that proposition.
*Dartmouth v. Posner*, 18 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: The language contained in the contract is unambiguous and, therefore, its interpretation is a question of law for the court to decide. ... Here, IDG entered into station commitments in all thirteen markets and the broadcasting deadline was met; therefore, IDG was obligated to pay the additional $7,500 fee to Singer.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 18.proposition: Defendant’s apparent retaliatory refusal to renew Plaintiff’s lease, despite Plaintiff’s protected activities of reporting code violations, further interferes with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment.

*Attorney Gen. v. Dime Sav. Bank of NY,.raw_text: *Attorney Gen. v. Dime Sav. Bank of NY, FSB*, 413 Mass. 284 (1992)
*Attorney Gen. v. Dime Sav. Bank of NY,.proposition: Defendant’s apparent retaliatory refusal to renew Plaintiff’s lease, despite Plaintiff’s protected activities of reporting code violations, further interferes with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment.
*Attorney Gen. v. Dime Sav. Bank of NY,.case_name: Attorney General v. Dime Savings Bank of New York, FSB
*Attorney Gen. v. Dime Sav. Bank of NY,.support_reasoning: The case concerns whether a foreclosing mortgagee may use a trespass action (with injunctive relief) to recover possession from holdover mortgagors or tenants, holding that summary process is the exclusive remedy under G.L. c. 184, § 18. It does not involve landlord retaliation, lease renewal decisions, code-violation reporting, or interference with quiet enjoyment. The proposition about an apparent retaliatory refusal to renew a lease exacerbating interference with quiet enjoyment is therefore unrelated to and unsupported by this opinion.
*Attorney Gen. v. Dime Sav. Bank of NY,.relevant_excerpt: "General Laws c. 184, § 18, provides, in pertinent part, that ‘[n]o person shall attempt to recover possession of land or tenements in any manner other than through an action brought pursuant to [G. L. c. 239] or such other proceedings authorized by law.’ … We therefore remand the matter to the county court for entry of a declaration that a mortgagee who forecloses on real property by sale may not bring a trespass action against a holdover tenant or mortgagor in actual possession of the foreclosed premises."
